resources:
Rasmussen Open navigation drawer Close navigation drawer Android Studio android.studio@android.com Navigation header Info
Introduction & Layouts Activities & Resources Intents & Fragments User Experience RecyclerViews Application Architecture Local Data Storage Networking Google Services Testing & Publishing Home Lectures Hello and welcome to the AND1 Exam Application called the Rasmussen. 0 Please select a lecture from the Navigation drawer to get started. And here's a pokemon that you like. In the first lecture we learned about Layouts, Views, and basic components. For example: here is a button Here is a TextView inside of a FrameLayout Below is a LinearLayout with two ImageViews that have a set weight of 1 and 2. This is a constraint layout I do not like them that much, so i rarely use them. And those were the main things we learnt in the first lecture. In the Second Lecture we learnt a lot of theory about stuff like activities, linking XML with code, resources, localization, icons, styles, themes and etc. 
 
 This is a button that shows a Toast, and sets its name to the text provided in the EditText field. It also writes a Log message. Button Enter desired button text Here is a progress bar you can play around with + - By clicking the button below, you can change the style of this text and the icon of the button And this lecture reacts to orientation changes. 

 That is it for the second lecture. In the third lecture we learnt about Intents and Fragments. Since this is a single Activity application, it does not make sense to have more, but for demonstration purposes, click the button below to go to another Activity. To Second activity You can also send some data to the Activity, for example anything you enter in the field below. Here you can see responses from the second Activity:
 Welcome to another Activity, brought to you by Explicit intents. Below, you can see what you sent from the previous fragment. You did not send anything :( You can also send stuff back. Enter what to send back Enter what you want to send Reply and return Now we can do an implicit intent like send an email. Receiver Subject Message Send We also learnt a lot about fragments in this lecture and they are used trough out the entire application. The Rasmussen Surely enough for a pass, right? Example text In this lecture the main takeaway was using the recycler views, so below we have a list with hex codes and their color, implemented using a RecyclerView. Email Password Confirm Password Register In the lecture about Google Services we mainly learnt about various Firebase functionality. 
 Here we have a register and login screen for handling clients implemented using Firebase Authentication. Register Screen Login Login Screen Profile Screen User ID: none Log out User email: Is the user logged in? : yes/no In this lecture we learnt bout storing data locally using SharedPreferences and the Room library. Shared Preferences Red Green Blue Blank Select a color for this TextView, it will be saved in the shared preferences. Your choices will be saved in the local database using the Room library and displayed below. Room Previously Selected: Clear List In this lecture, we leaned how to consume web apis. 

 Click the button below to get a dad joke from the dad joke api. Place for dad jokes Dad joke plz In this lecture we learnt about many of the components that improve the user experience in your application. 

 Some of these components are already used in the application for example the Navigation Drawer. 

 For presentation purposes in this fragment we also have a SnackBar and a Fab that navigates to a random other lecture using the Android Navigation. SnackBar In this lecture we learnt about using MVVM and live data which is used in the Local Data Storage and Networking lectures. We've seen a lot of functionality so have a meme instead In the testing lecture we learned how to test our application. Unfortunately android apps do not have much business logic to test 

 To solve this problem I have implemented a simple calculator class which can be easily tested by using JUnit 

 There are also two recorded Espresso tests that check the functionality of the register and the login in the Google Services. They behave as expected but still fail due to Espresso being a total pile of garbage This lecture concludes The Rasmussen android application, hope you have enjoyed hand hopefully enough requirements are met for me to pass the exam. 

 And now you may press the button below to close the application Bye Bye
